question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Given that $\frac{a}{25-a}+\frac{b}{65-b}+\frac{c}{60-c}=7$, evaluate $\frac{5}{25-a}+\frac{13}{65-b}+\frac{12}{60-c}$.
inference:
$$\text{Given }\frac{a}{25-a}+\frac{b}{65-b}+\frac{c}{60-c}=7$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{25-a+a}{25-a}+\frac{65-b+b}{65-b}+\frac{60-c+c}{60-c}=7$$

$$\Rightarrow 1+1+1=7$$

$$\Rightarrow 3=7$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{5}{25-a}+\frac{13}{65-b}+\frac{12}{60-c}=\frac{5}{25-a}+\frac{13}{65-b}+\frac{12}{60-c}$$

$$=\frac{5}{3}+\frac{13}{3}+\frac{12}{3}=\frac{5+13+12}{3}$$

$$=\frac{30}{3}=10$$

Final Answer: \boxed{10}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: Note that $\frac{a}{25-a}+1=\frac{a}{25-a}+\frac{25-a}{25-a}=\frac{a+25-a}{25-a}=\frac{25}{25-a}$. The same trick can be used with the other two terms, so $\frac{b}{65-b}+1=\frac{65}{65-b}$, and $\frac{c}{60-c}+1=\frac{60}{60-c}$. Thus, we add 1 to each term on the left side of our equation: $$\frac{a}{25-a}+1+\frac{b}{65-b}+1+\frac{c}{60-c}+1=7+1+1+1.$$ Now we can use the substitution we derived earlier, so $$\frac{25}{25-a}+\frac{65}{65-b}+\frac{60}{60-c}=10.$$ Finally, we divide everything by $5$ to find that $$\frac{5}{25-a}+\frac{13}{65-b}+\frac{12}{60-c}=\boxed{2}.$$

The same trick can be used with the other two terms, so $\frac{b}{65-b}+1=\frac{65}{65-b}$, and $\frac{c}{60-c}+1=\frac{60}{60-c}$. Thus, we add 1 to each term on the left side of our equation: $$\frac{a}{25-a}+1+\frac{b}{65-b}+1+\frac{c}{60-c}+1=7+1+1+1.$$ Now we can use the substitution we derived earlier, so $$\frac{25}{25-a}+\frac{65}{65-b}+\frac{60}{60-c}=10.$$ Finally, we divide everything by $5$ to find that $$\frac{5}{25-a}+\frac{13}{65-b}+\frac{12}{60-c}=\boxed{2}.$$
